snippet: As the Communist state collapsed, so did its powerful skating program, but as the standard of living slowly improved, an increasing number of ice rinks lured athletes back to the sport.
abstract: Russia faced exodus of figure skating talent following collapse of Soviet Union in 1991, draining prowess from its once-prominent skating program; story of Maxim Trankov and Tatiana Volosozhar, Russian pair with best chance of winning gold at the Sochi Games, illustrates how improved standard of living has led to a skating resurgence.
lead_paragraph: As the Communist state collapsed, so did its powerful skating program, but as the standard of living slowly improved, an increasing number of ice rinks lured athletes back to the sport.

headline.main: Long After Soviet Fall, Russian Pairs Climb Back Up
headline.print_headline: Long After Soviet Fall, Russian Pairs Regain Footing
